channel.title: The simplest audio oscillator
channel.description:
Yeah... I left an important project to late and I need to make [i]the simplest[/i] audio oscillator from the least parts possible seeing as my collection of bits and pieces is in a total mess... It would be nice to not have to use more than two transistors (please... no pnp ones >.<) I only have polarized capacitors so please no non polarized capacitors. (>.<) I'll need to be able to hook it up to a 9v battery (always put a small resistor in the circuit) and I'll need to be able to hook it up to an 8Ohm speaker.
So yeah It would be nice to have a schematic before 3pm BST
Thanks in advance but if you can't help. Oh well :rolleyes:
(Im going to bed now and... need to make a simple case as well so yeah busy day tommorow

item.title: The simplest audio oscillator
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

well, the simplest way would be to put a resistor and capacitor in series, it wouldn’t be a perfect sinewave, but seeing as you said you wanted it simple it should do.

the time it takes to complete a full wave would be 10 * C * R, so the frequency would be 1/10/C/R.
I can’t remember the circuit diagram though, I will try and get back to you later.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: August 07, 2009, 10:05:25 am[/size][hr]ok, here’s a circuit closely resembling the one I was thinking of:
